channel.title: Let's talk about the Crowbar
channel.description:
Am I the only one here with the feeling that the crowbar is unreasonably OP? Even on hard, if I'm in melee range of something, I can kill it right goddamn fast, much faster than with anything short of explosives. It hits hard and in abnormally quick succession after landing the initial blow. This is off-putting and removes much of the immersion of having an "under-dog" weapon.
[u][b]This is what I suggest;[/b][/u]
[b]1)[/b] Make each hit have [i]weight[/i], aka, each blow isn't immediately followed with another blow moments after the initial. Allow 1-1.5 seconds between blows.
[b]2)[/b] Make each hit have [i]force[/i], aka, minor increase in damage to account for the slower speeds.
[b]3)[/b] Please [b]remake the animations[/b]. Is it possible to have an actual swing associated with the crowbar, instead of some instantaneous love-tap that looks like it'd sooner annoy a headcrab than kill it? Make the damned thing swing!
I may be alone in my opinions with the crowbar, but it's literally the only thing that stood out to me as a gameplay killer. Where the rest of the weapons have some fantastic love put into them, from textures to animations, it's shocking to see the weapon iconic with the brand be the most lazily represented.

I swear some of you people on this forum don’t know how to look at an example and not take it for face value. I didn’t say “The crowbar is shit because there wasn’t a cool intro.” I stated an example of what could’ve happened, not necessarily what should’ve happened. And again, it was just an example. It’s not like I’m in any place to produce anything to showcase what I mean, which is why I civilly outlined what I thought was wrong and followed up with suggestions.

Ever hear of constructive criticism? My OP is how you do it. Not jumping on the “omg BMS is perfect” bandwagon. It’s far from and this entire subsection of the forums was dedicated to that effort.

I like the idea of the HL2 crowbar. Would just like to see something new and original, if that’s possible, since the rest of BMS has a very ‘built-from-the-ground-up’ feeling.

Then what the hell were you talking about when referring to it being “lazily implemented”? If it’s just the animations, then that’s already been discussed to death. And even if it isn’t, what else would a long metal stick have going for it besides just hitting things? Giving it too much power could disrupt the balance of the game somewhat. It’s perfectly fine as a tool for breaking things and killing headcrabs.

Also, if you’ve seen me post before, then you’d know that I know all about constructive criticism. Not once have I claimed that BMS is perfect. I’ve criticized and nitpicked the shit out of it. Stop jumping to conclusions.

item.title: Let's talk about the Crowbar
item.dc:creator: Unit24
item.description:
Thatamos:

However I stand by my original statement, that indeed, the crowbar is “lazily represented” compared to the rest of BMS. Something I found odd given the iconic nature of said crowbar.

Quick example for clarification-- I don’t remember the original pistol from HL1 having any feeling of power as a direct result of the sound quality, or a cool fippy spin idle animation, but I have that feeling and animation in BMS-- a clear improvement from the original. Why was the crowbar kept at the exact same quality as the original, if not at least the same quality as the one from HL2? Why was there no cool introductory animation when you first found it, as if greeting a long lost friend, a simple and fun ode to the players who’ll be exploring BMS?

I didn’t bash any other part of the game. I didn’t say it was bad. It’s pretty fucking fantastic, enough that I’ve been telling all of my friends who own a laptop and desktop to go download it and enjoy.

But the crowbar is lazily represented.

They weren’t being lazy, they just decided not to overdo it. Why does it need a super fancy introductory animation? It’s a crowbar. It’s a long metal stick that you hit things with. True, it’s the “iconic” weapon of the series, but that doesn’t mean that it needs to rain confetti from the ceiling when you get it.

Plus, the way you get it in BM is a very hectic moment in which you’re attacked about two seconds after picking it up. An introductory animation would only take away from the moment. Acquiring the crowbar is treated as a heat-of-the-moment survival decision, rather than the discovery of the holy grail.

However it does deserve more fluid and powerful looking animations.
